title: Justice Officials Allow Cooperative to Purchase Dean Foods Dairy Plants
summary: Justice Department announced an antitrust settlement to allow Dairy Farmers of America to buy the bulk of Dean's plants out of bankruptcy. Justice Department antitrust authorities cleared the way for Dairy Farmers of America Inc. to buy the bulk of Dean Foods Co. 's milk plants out of bankruptcy, uniting the nation's largest dairy cooperative by membership with the biggest milk processor.

title: Testing Isn't Everything
summary: It won't banish the coronavirus, and it's not an excuse for not opening.. Many states are starting to lift their shutdown orders, but some governors are still insisting they need more testing to do so. The Trump Administration on Monday responded by laying out all of the country's testing capacity. But no amount of testing by itself will stop the virus from spreading. States will need a cocktail of strategies to limit the spread of infections.

title: The Judge and Michael Flynn
summary: New documents suggest violations of the Brady rule on evidence.. Federal Judge Emmet Sullivan is overseeing the prosecution of former National Security Adviser Mike Flynn, who is accused of lying to the FBI. The judge now has a second issue of fact and law to examine-to wit, whether prosecutors withheld crucial information from the Flynn defense.

title: Drug Innovation to the Rescue
summary: Profits from much-maligned Sovaldi helped Gilead's research.. The world hasn't had much good news of late, but some arrived on Friday as the Food and Drug Administration approved the emergency use of the drug remdesivir to treat Covid-19 patients. This underscores that drug innovation, especially by private American companies, is the best hope we have for defeating the coronavirus.

title: Biden's #MeToo Denial
summary: He rewrites his past statements on 'believe the woman.'. Joe Biden was categorical Friday in denying that he sexually assaulted then-staffer Tara Reade in 1993. "This never happened," he told Mika Brzezinski of MSNBC. "It's as simple as that."

title: Government Punts to Business
summary: Spontaneous deregulation is happening as politicians turn to the public to fix the lockdown mess.. A series of European and U.S. cartel prosecutions in the 1990s provided fodder for a question that engaged this column in more languorous times: When do executives find it irresistible to engage in illegal price fixing?

title: U.S. States Roll Back Restrictions as Lockdowns Ease Across Asia
summary: Tensions flare in some places where restrictive policies remain. The U.S. began a piecemeal reopening of its economy Friday, as Texas, Alabama and other states relaxed stay-at-home measures.

title: Coronavirus Forces Teachers to Learn a Different Tune
summary: An elementary school music teacher tries to navigate digital platforms while playing the ukulele.. Columbia, S.C.

title: FDA Authorizes Emergency Use of Remdesivir for Covid-19 Patients
summary: Action comes after research shows the drug shortened recovery times in patients. WASHINGTON-The Food and Drug Administration authorized the emergency use of the drug remdesivir in Covid-19 patients after researchers reported that it shortened the recovery times in people who have fallen ill from the new coronavirus.

title: Differing Rules Show Lack of Consensus on State Reopenings
summary: Wide differences between-and even within-states play out as officials and businesspeople try to balance medical and economic risks. In Oklahoma, hair salons began welcoming back clients this week; next door in Kansas, they remain empty.

title: Simon Property Group, Kraft Heinz, United Parcel Service: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Simon Property Group Inc.

title: U.S. Probes University of Texas Links to Chinese Lab
summary: Education Department investigation into foreign financial ties also seeks records of school system's dealings with Huawei, Zoom CEO. The Education Department has asked the University of Texas System to provide documentation of its dealings with the Chinese laboratory U.S. officials are investigating as a potential source of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Justice Department Files Charges Against Former Blue Bell CEO
summary: Paul Kruse previously led ice-cream maker tied to deadly listeria outbreak. The Justice Department filed criminal charges against a former ice-cream executive and his company, Blue Bell Creameries LP, which agreed to plead guilty and pay a $19 million fine related to a 2015 listeria outbreak tied to three deaths and a number of other illnesses.

title: Cohen Remains in Prison Amid Confusion Over Release Policy
summary: President Trump's former lawyer had previously been told he would begin home confinement on Friday. WASHINGTON-Michael Cohen, President Trump's former lawyer, didn't return home as scheduled on Friday from federal prison, a person familiar with the matter said, amid broader confusion over how prison officials are releasing inmates to home confinement to stem the spread of the new coronavirus behind bars.

title: 'James Monroe: A Life' Review: His Competency
summary: Jefferson's mind was the most capacious, Madison's the most rapid-but stolid, solid Monroe's the most sure.. James Monroe, the fifth president (1817-25), is most remembered for the Doctrine bearing his name and promulgated in his second term. The Monroe Doctrine laid the lines of America's hemispheric and trans-Atlantic policy until World War I, and its spirit remains intermittently influential, long after its prescriptions have been superseded. Tim McGrath's biography "James Monroe: A Life" shows how Monroe's character and experiences over a long career shaped his doctrine: a worthy capstone of an interesting public life.

title: Amazon CEO Bezos Called to Testify Before Congress
summary: Lawmakers want to know if the retailing giant used data about independent sellers on its platform to develop competing products. Lawmakers on the House Judiciary Committee called on Amazon.com Inc. Chairman and CEO Jeff Bezos to testify on its private-label practices, citing a Wall Street Journal investigation that found Amazon employees used data about independent sellers on its platform to develop competing products.

title: Canadian Military Crew Presumed Dead After Crash
summary: The five missing Canadians aboard an ill-fated military helicopter are now presumed dead, bringing the presumed death toll to six. OTTAWA-Canada's defense department said Friday the five missing air force and navy officers aboard a military helicopter that crashed this week off the coast of Greece following a training exercise are now presumed dead.

title: 'Great State' Review: Rising and Setting in the East
summary: This is not a book about how China's past shapes its present. It is simply a work-a fascinating one-about China's past.. In October 1603, tensions between Chinese merchant settlers and the Spanish authorities in Manila exploded into open violence, in which 20,000 Chinese were killed. The problems traced back to a delegation from Ming China that had arrived the previous summer to check on the Chinese merchants in the city. The Spanish feared that this was a prelude to a Chinese invasion.

title: 'The Fairest of Them All' Review: Grimm and Grimmer
summary: She is 'Sodewa Bai' in India and 'Snaefridr' in Nordic regions. One trait never changes: unsurpassed beauty.. When Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," the first feature-length animated fairy tale, was released in 1937, it was a global sensation. It found particular favor in Nazi Germany, where Adolf Hitler secured a private screening and Joseph Goebbels, his propaganda minister, gushed over the revival of a Germanic folktale about a maiden with "skin as white as snow." ("An artistic delight!" he declared.) The Nazi high command may have been disappointed to discover that there is nothing definitively or originally German about Snow White, however. Her tale has turned up in countries as disparate as Hungary, Italy, Afghanistan, Japan, Armenia and Sudan. As Maria Tatar writes in "The Fairest of Them All: Snow White and 21 Tales of Mothers and Daughters," Snow White "can be found in nearly every place that stories are told, and she rarely has white skin."

title: The Satisfactions of Confinement Cooking
summary: In an anxious time, the family kitchen has become a place for comfort and togetherness.. This is not going to be one of those articles that tells you that Covid-19 is actually great because we are all cooking more. There are levels of bleakness that no amount of sourdough baking can cure.

title: Remdesivir Affirms the American Way
summary: Gilead Sciences failed for years to prove its efficacy, but patent law and markets helped it to persevere.. The Food and Drug Administration has authorized the use of Gilead Sciences ' drug remdesivir to treat severely ill Covid-19 patients. Previously, Gilead announced that it was donating all its existing supply, 1.5 million doses, free of charge. The FDA's Emergency Use Authorization and the company's extraordinary action give a tremendous boost to a world in crisis.

title: Powell Calendar Shows Meetings During a Critical Interval
summary: Fed chairman spoke to President Trump, BlackRock CEO Laurence Fink. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell spoke regularly with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, U.S. lawmakers and foreign central bankers during a critical mid-March interval where the Fed sought to prevent the coronavirus pandemic from unleashing a financial crisis.

title: White House Press Secretary Returns to Podium
summary: Kayleigh McEnany holds first official briefing as daily coronavirus task force briefings taper off. WASHINGTON-The White House press secretary was at the podium on Friday for the first time in 417 days.

title: Treasury Yields Are Supported by Borrowing Binge
summary: Corporate bond sales have surged as businesses raise cash to ride out the effects of the pandemic. U.S. government bond prices edged lower Friday even as stocks fell sharply, a sign that some demand for Treasurys was being soaked up by a record-setting influx of new debt into the market.

title: Tech Giants Pull Stocks Lower as Dow Falls More Than 600 Points
summary: S&P falls nearly 3% after Amazon, Apple show they aren't immune to coronavirus slowdown. The technology heavyweights that powered the recent market rebound stumbled Friday, dragging down the broader stock market.

title: Taliban Attacks Increased After Peace Deal
summary: Defense Department has classified data on the number of attacks, which formerly were public information. WASHINGTON-The U.S. recorded an increase in Taliban attacks against Afghan forces for March after signing a peace deal with the insurgent group, a government watchdog office said Friday, contrary to hopes that the agreement would lead to less violence.

title: Struggling With Remote Learning, Some Families Cut Class
summary: 'The priority is peace in the home': During coronavirus, parents and students balance school demands with emotional needs. One New York City mother got so exasperated by alerts on her cellphone saying it was time for her young daughter to start virtual classes, wash hands or take a break that she blocked the teacher's phone number.

title: Bill and Melinda Gates: The Better World That You Will Build
summary: Think about your own role, however large or small, in making the world a better place for everyone. Most commencement addresses do not change the course of history. On a sunny afternoon in 1947, then-Secretary of State George C. Marshall gave one that did.

title: Rising Natural Gas Prices Are a Hot Bet
summary: Investors are unwinding wagers that prices will fall, bidding up producers' beaten-down shares and even buying their new bonds. Natural gas is flaring up.

title: Mistakes to Avoid When Refinancing Student Loans
summary: It could be an answer for some parents. But before deciding, it is helpful to understand the options.. With interest rates trending low again, some families might be thinking about ways to lower their monthly student-debt payments

title: Ultra Petroleum Nears Another Bankruptcy, Showing Limits Of a Popular Trade
summary: Hedge funds took control of shale drillers when prices collapsed years ago and are now stuck with losing bets. Ultra Petroleum Corp. is preparing to file for chapter 11 protection for the second time since 2016, according to people familiar with the matter, a sign of how some oil-and-gas companies that cleaned up their balance sheets in recent years are buckling once again.

title: Gerard Baker: Don't Worry, Remain Open to Surprise and Find Your Love
summary: And best to skip the bad suit and the little Italian sports car. As an immigrant to this country, I love American graduations. Commencement speeches were a completely alien concept in the U.K., where I grew up. My graduation ceremony was conducted entirely in Latin. We knelt in neat rows, dressed head to foot in something called "subfusc," in front of a man attired like a character from an Edwardian comic opera, who tapped us each on the head with a copy of the Bible before we all traipsed outside to reunite with baffled family members.

title: U.S. Moves to Curb Foreign Electric Gear
summary: Trump administration strategy is intended to protect nation's electricity grid from attacks by foreign powers including China and Russia. President Trump signed an executive order intended to limit the use of foreign-supplied components in the nation's electric grid, declaring that the practice poses an "extraordinary threat to national security."

title: TheSkimm Cuts 20% of Staff Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: Founders Danielle Weisberg and Carly Zakin pledge to take pay cuts, plan only one round of layoffs. TheSkimm, a news-curation company known primarily for its current-events newsletter, is laying off about 20% of its staff of about 130 employees, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: U.S. Auto Sales Plunged in April, but Signs of Hope Are Seen
summary: While stay-at-home orders dented industry sales, deeper discounts and shift to online retailing helped blunt damage. Several major auto makers said April was one of their worst sales months in decades, but many dealers and executives are also reporting signs of optimism as potential buyers begin to emerge from coronavirus lockdowns.

title: A View to Die For
summary: Alfred Hitchcock's 'Rear Window' is a mystery that, in our current moment, resonates as a poignant portrait of boredom in confinement..

title: A Fictional Portrait Brought to Life
summary: Artist Noah Saterstrom created a painting that was imagined by novelist Ann Patchett. For the Nashville-based artist Noah Saterstrom, portraiture is more a matter of intuition than replication. Mr. Saterstrom, 46, is known for his collagelike depictions of Southern writers such as William Faulkner and Richard Ford. Often he derives inspiration from recordings of writers' voices as much as from photographs of their faces. Raised in Mississippi, he also drew on youthful memories for his portrait of Eudora Welty, whom he regularly saw during the 1990s around Jackson, the state capital.

title: WHO Warns Countries Could Face Food Shortages Due to Virus Travel Restrictions
summary: Organization adds the coronavirus pandemic remains a global health emergency. The World Health Organization warned of possible food shortages in some countries due to global travel restrictions in place to limit the spread of coronavirus.

title: Shutdown Spinners
summary: Even where the curves have flattened, lockdowns continue.. It isn't easy persuading some politicians to let us have our economy and our liberty back. This column recently expressed the hope that encouraging data might inspire the shutdown caucus to declare victory and lift the lockdowns. But dramatic declines in new cases, hospitalizations and deaths in hot spot New York City and downward curves statewide have somehow persuaded New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo to cancel the rest of the school year.

title: Why Joe Biden's Senate Papers Aren't Public
summary: The University of Delaware says they will be available two years after the presidential candidate retires from public life. Former Vice President Joe Biden's denial Friday of a sexual-assault allegation against him by a former Senate aide has renewed questions about access to documents from his Senate career that are stored at his alma mater, the University of Delaware.

title: Annette Gordon-Reed: Preparing to Move On in a Time of Losses
summary: Put your disappointments in context-and learn from this stress test of American government and society.. First, I want to say how deeply sorry I am about the circumstances that make this type of commencement address necessary. Students in their final year are special. They are on the cusp of finishing a multiyear journey that has inevitably helped transform them in ways anticipated and not.

title: Blood-Pressure Drugs Don't Raise Coronavirus Risk
summary: It is safe to continue taking your blood-pressure medications, researchers said. Common blood-pressure medicines don't raise patients' risks of infection, serious illness or death from the new coronavirus, three large studies published Friday found, helping settle a question potentially affecting millions of people.

title: Elon Musk Tweeted That Tesla's Stock Was Too High. The Market Agreed.
summary: Car maker's shares fall after comment; asked if tweet was vetted or made in jest, CEO says 'No'. Tesla Inc. stock fell Friday morning after Chief Executive Elon Musk took to Twitter to say the auto maker's share price was "too high" in a series of messages he posted on the social-media platform.

title: Fannie Mae Income Drops as More Homeowners Suspend Mortgage Payments
summary: Government-controlled mortgage finance giant predicts suspensions on loans it guarantees will double. Fannie Mae , the government-controlled mortgage finance giant, reported a steep drop in income as it set aside more money for expected loan losses, and it projected further trouble ahead as more Americans suspend payments on their home loans.

title: The Fed Can't Do It All, Says Alan Blinder
summary: The former Federal Reserve vice chairman says he approves of how the Fed is responding to the economic and financial havoc wrought by the coronavirus. Alan Blinder knows a thing or two about the Federal Reserve, having served as vice chairman from 1994 to 1996 and as a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers before that.

title: Fortunes Flip as Shoppers Ditch Makeup, Stock Up on Cleaning Supplies
summary: Clorox boosts outlook amid coronavirus pandemic while Estée Lauder logs weakest quarter since recession. Americans' dramatically altered spending habits amid the coronavirus pandemic upended financial results for some of the biggest consumer-products companies.

title: Canada Bans More Than 1,500 Types of Military-Style Firearms
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Trudeau discusses eventual aim of giving cities the power to ban handguns. OTTAWA-Canada on Friday banned over 1,500 models of military-style assault firearms, effective immediately, a move that fulfills an election-campaign promise from last year and emerges roughly two weeks after the deadliest shooting rampage in the country's modern history.

title: Ferrari's Back-to-Work Plan Starts With a Blood Test
summary: The Italian auto maker is among the first big companies to offer antibody tests to employees. MARANELLO, Italy-Ferrari NV's normally bustling factory and headquarters here stood mostly deserted earlier this week, except for the line of employees waiting to have their blood drawn and tested for coronavirus antibodies.

title: Jon Hamm Will Read You a Bedtime Story
summary: Celebrity storytellers are spinning their yarns on Instagram. Story hour at bookstores and libraries around the country may be shelved for the time being, but a number of well-known storytellers are turning to Instagram with a temporary workaround. Launched in mid March by Amy Adams and Jennifer Garner, the account @savewithstories posts boldfaced names-Steve Carell, Kate Winslet, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Jenny Slate, Ne-Yo, and Jon Hamm among them-reading kiddies books aloud as a way to drum up support for the non-profits Save the Children and No Kid Hungry. And every Thursday at 7 p.m. ET through June 4th, Dolly Parton hosts her own storytime gig @dollyparton (it's also posted on YouTube, Facebook and Twitter ). Over in Brooklyn, novelist Emma Straub is doing readings for her bookshop Books Are Magic (@booksaremagicbk) every Saturday and Sunday at 11 a.m. ET, while on the West Coast, author Mac Barnett, based in Oakland, Calif., gets up to 25,000 views from kids in 50 countries, including Iran and South Korea, for his "Mac's Book Club Show" (@macbarnett). "Gathering together to listen to stories is one of the most human things we can do-it's one of the first ways we formed communities," Mr. Barnett said. "I hope I provide some structure and joy for kids each day."

title: Fed's Bullard Warns Shutdown Could Lead to Lasting Economic Damage
summary: The St. Louis Fed President calls shutdown 'very blunt instrument' and sees eventual need for a 'far more granular, far more risk-based' approach to operating economy. Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard warned Friday that an extended shutdown of the U.S. economy to deal with the coronavirus crisis was ultimately unworkable and could lead to lasting, deep damage.

title: For Small Businesses With High Rents, Coronavirus Aid Falls Short
summary: Companies face burden as $660 billion program places limits on rent and other key costs. WASHINGTON-The federal government's $660 billion aid program for small businesses coping with the coronavirus pandemic threatens to leave hundreds of thousands of companies struggling to survive because of its limits on nonpayroll expenses.

title: Three Questions With Small-Business Owner Cate Luzio
summary: In less than a month, she's converted a company that stressed in-person networking into a virtual business. Like many other small-business owners, Cate Luzio has made some tough choices in recent weeks.

title: Apollo Is Latest Private-Equity Firm Hammered by Coronavirus Rout
summary: Firm was hurt by sharp decline at Athene, an insurance company in its portfolio. Apollo Global Management Inc. reported a first-quarter loss, becoming the third publicly traded private-equity firm to take a hit to the value of its investments because of the coronavirus-driven market rout. But the firm also saw the quarter as a buying opportunity, pouring tens of billions of dollars into investments.

title: Exxon: Heavy Lies the Dividend Crown
summary: Exxon has raised eyebrows for continuing its payout, but its behavior has been consistent and makes sense given the falling returns from its business. Shell may be the company with "royal" in its name, but Exxon Mobil is the one that feels honor bound to blue-blooded tradition.

title: New York Schools Will Stay Closed for Academic Year Due to Coronavirus
summary: Cuomo says closures affect more than 4 million public, private school and college students statewide. Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Friday that K-12 schools and colleges will remain closed for the rest of the academic year across New York, and they will continue to provide distance learning.

title: Coronavirus Prompts Biggest U.S. Manufacturing Pullback Since Last Recession
summary: April index reading of 41.5% was the lowest level since April 2009. U.S. manufacturing contracted at the sharpest rate since the last recession in April as companies pulled back following lockdowns to halt the spread of the coronavirus.

title: For Manufacturers, an Unprecedented Hit
summary: A close reading of survey data suggests U.S. manufacturers are seeing their toughest times since at least the end of World War II. Manufacturers have seen hard times before. But not like this.

title: What Would You Risk for a Faster Cure?
summary: Michael Milken, the billionaire former financier, is boosting Covid treatments. No one knows which will work, but saving lives and the economy will require a mighty gamble.. Try to remember when you first heard of the new virus sickening thousands in Wuhan, China. After that, how soon did you know that it would be a global pandemic?

title: The Road to Surfdom
summary: California's beach closure is tough on those who can't afford backyard pools.. Tustin, Calif.

title: Sustainability Was Corporate America's Buzzword. This Crisis Changes That.
summary: From Unilever to Starbucks to GM, corporations pause some social-responsibility programs or put them on the back burner. Lauren Singer had spent the last eight years living a "zero-waste" life and building an eco-friendly business off of it. Then, the coronavirus pandemic confronted the chief executive of New York-based Package Free with an existential crisis.

title: Today's Logistics Report: Shipping's Bet on Trade; Amazon's Soaring Costs; Stores' Opening Hours
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain & Logistics News. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: 'Careerist' Toys From Your Past That Children Still Love
summary: The microscope. The rock tumbler. The rocket kit. As a kid, you loved toys that let you mimic adult work. Despite the rise of videogames, here's why today's kids gravitate to them, too.. WHY ARE TOYS that let children mimic the quotidian chores of adult careers-such as counting cash like a bank teller or peering through microscope slides like a yawning researcher-so appealing to little ones? You'd think they'd have better things to do.

title: Yuval Noah Harari: Rebellion of the Hackable Animals
summary: Defending freedom will be even more urgent once government can use technology to look into our innermost feelings.. Commencement speeches are usually an occasion to give graduates advice, but instead I'd like to ask for your help in dealing with an unprecedented challenge to humanity. You have probably heard many times that your smartphone can be hacked. But the real game-changer is that soon, corporations and governments might be able to hack your body and brain. The most important thing to know about the 21st century is that humans are becoming hackable animals.

title: Facebook Warned That It May Lose a Key Seal of Approval for Ad Gauge
summary: Media rating council says social-media giant could be denied accreditation. Facebook Inc. is at risk of losing a key seal of approval that gives companies confidence they are getting what they pay for when it comes to advertising with the social-media giant.

title: Coronavirus Canceled Buffett's Shareholder Party. Omaha Is Suffering.
summary: Local businesses are missing one of their biggest revenue opportunities of the year without a Berkshire Hathaway meeting that typically generates $21 million for Nebraska's largest city. 'This is your moneymaking weekend.'. Warren Buffett's "Woodstock for Capitalists" was effectively canceled this year, dealing a huge blow to Omaha's economy.

title: Hong Kong Protesters, Police Resume Clashes
summary: As pandemic shows signs of abating, pro-democracy demonstrators seek to revive mass support. HONG KONG--Riot police used pepper spray to clear demonstrators from a shopping mall Friday, the first clash in months as the city's antigovernment movement sought to revive protests after a lull during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Autoliv's New CFO Forced to Make Tough Choices Amid Coronavirus Crisis
summary: Swedish auto-parts supplier navigates shutdown of production while also preparing for ramp-up in certain markets. Just weeks into his new job, Autoliv Inc.'s finance chief found himself facing some tough decisions as auto production in North America and Europe shut down due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: London Bankers' Failed Rehab
summary: It's frowned upon to fire anyone in Britain right now-except for investment bankers. In the current crisis it has become reputationally risky for British companies to lay off anyone. Well, almost anyone. Firing investment bankers-the villains of the previous crisis-doesn't seem to be a problem.

title: Women's Apparel Company J. Jill Taps Restructuring Advisers After Closing Stores
summary: Like many retailers, J. Jill is seeking flexibility from its lenders amid the pandemic. Women's clothing retailer J. Jill Inc. has hired advisers to help fix its balance sheet after it had to close its stores due to the coronavirus pandemic, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: 'Atomic Spy' Review: The Soviets' Secret Weapon
summary: Given the high stakes of the race for an atomic weapon, MI5 ignored the allegations on file about the physicist's communist past. On the afternoon of Feb. 10, 1933, in the north German city of Kiel, a bespectacled math prodigy was lifted off his feet by a crowd of Nazi Brownshirts and tossed into the freezing waters of the Baltic Sea. Left for dead, he somehow swam to safety. His name was Klaus Fuchs. Until then he had been a socialist who had joined the local Communist Party only as a last resort, to do more in the fight against Nazism. But this political baptism altered his outlook. It was the starting point in an explosive chain reaction-akin to the atomic chain reactions he would soon be studying in his pioneering work as a scientist-that would lead to Klaus Fuchs being described by the U.S. Congress, in 1951, as a man who "influenced the safety of more people and accomplished greater damage than any other spy not only in the history of the United States but in the history of nations."

title: 'Sorry for Your Trouble' Review: Setting Out and Putting In
summary: A collection of stories that is both a coherent work of art and a pellucid window on America's moneyed middle class.. 'Our Day of dependence, our long apprenticeship to the learning of other lands, draws to a close. The millions that around us are rushing into life cannot always be fed on the sere remains of foreign harvests." So Ralph Waldo Emerson announced in a speech delivered at Harvard in 1837, later published as "The American Scholar." The essay can plausibly be regarded as the second Declaration of Independence. In it, the sage of Concord gave notice that America was not the backward child of Europe but a new phenomenon in the world, a new kind of nation, self-reliant and sufficient unto itself.

title: Five Best: Susanna Moore on Hollywood Lives
summary: The author, most recently, of the memoir 'Miss Aluminum.'. By Carlotta Monti With Cy Rice (1971)

title: Confession of a Burned-Out Quarantine Chef
summary: I was a kitchen master for three weeks. Now I'm down to chewing on sticks and old toast.. Amid our national shelter-in-place, there's been some hope that, at the very least, America may be experiencing an at-home culinary revolution. Banished to our kitchens, forced to dive deep into our spice racks, finally learning the difference between baking powder and baking soda-who knew?-we are locating our inner Julias and Jacqueses, becoming the semi-masterful master chefs we always aspired to be.

title: 'In the Waves' Review: Up She Rises
summary: The Hunley was the ﬁrst submarine to destroy an enemy ship. Until recently, the sinking of the Confederate craft was an abiding mystery of the Civil War.. Most people don't understand explosions. In action movies, we see heroes, propelled by fireballs, get back up, then brush themselves off before jumping back into the fray. But in the real world, the pressure wave from a nearby explosion can kill you without even knocking you over. "Our action hero, thrown across the room by the winds of an explosion," writes Rachel Lance in her book "In the Waves," "is not standing up and dashing off after a mild back injury." Instead, the blunt trauma to his lungs will kill him "100 percent of the time."

title: 'Empires of the Sky' Review: Magnificent Men, Flying Machines
summary: A German count created an airship held aloft by hydrogen. A Yalie created a major airline to compete with it.. Ferdinand von Zeppelin was a minor nobleman from the kingdom of Württemberg, in what is now southwest Germany. In 1863, as a lieutenant in the Royal Army, the king allowed him to tour other countries and study their military technology. The U.S. Civil War was of particular interest. Lodging at Washington's Willard Hotel, young Zeppelin talked himself into an audience with Abraham Lincoln, who obligingly signed a pass for him to visit the Union armies at the front. For all the country's democratic pretensions, as Alexander Rose tells us in his delightful and informative "Empires of the Sky," Zeppelin marveled at the courtesy he received: "Nowhere is so much fuss made about a simple traveling count."

title: Children's Books: Stories Can Take You Anywhere
summary: Siblings that journey beyond rivalry; woodland creatures on a quest.. Any child can tell you that it matters enormously who gets to press the buttons in an elevator. If you're not the designated button-pusher, you may have to watch a sibling flaunt the privilege. If you're the anointed one, you may guard your status into adolescence. So when children open Minh Lê and Dan Santat's perceptive picture book "Lift" (Little, Brown, 48 pages, $17.99), they know the score.

title: Graduation During Coronavirus: A Little Pomp, Under the Circumstances
summary: Resume Subscription. New Jersey high school principal Glenn Lottmann recently unveiled his plan for this year's graduation. It starts with about 315 seniors being driven by their parents or guardians to assemble in a procession at Woodbridge High School.

title: Mysteries: How to Survive in Outlaw Country
summary: A semiretired investigator is tasked with solving the killing of a gambler whose loot has been stolen.. Brian Panowich wowed critics with his first two linked rural-noir novels involving a conflicted lawman struggling to serve justice in the clannish Blue Ridge foothills of north Georgia. His third novel, "Hard Cash Valley" (Minotaur, 292 pages, $26.99), introduces a new character from the same patch of territory: 37-year-old Dane Kirby, a semi-retired arson investigator and ex-sheriff who is now a part-time consultant for the Georgia Bureau of Investigation.

title: Fiction: The Pedantry to Which Her Prose Inclines
summary: Eimear McBride's hotel-haunting new heroine thinks in a gloriously fastidious English that keeps the moral untidiness of her life in check.. Though the novel as an art form is hardly dead, as doomsayers are forever declaring, it does sometimes feel as though it's being henpecked into submission. Contemporary fiction writers seem to work as if from a defensive crouch, preemptively bracing for the reprimands of identity-politics police from one side and anti-intellectuals from the other. Even the most exciting and inventive novelists have been shaped by an aesthetics of embarrassment-see the sheepish, performatively ironic poets in Ben Lerner's fiction, or the main character of Eimear McBride's latest novel, "Strange Hotel" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 149 pages, $25), who refers to her own narration as "pedantry" and "pseudo-intellectual garble."

title: Ford Names Daughter of Chairman to Company's Board Seat at Rivian
summary: Appointment at electric-car startup marks rise of another Ford in the auto maker's ranks. Ford Motor Co. has appointed Alexandra Ford English, daughter of executive chairman Bill Ford Jr., to fill the company's board seat at electric-car startup Rivian Automotive, signaling the rise of another young Ford within the company's ranks.

title: Cruise Ships Set Sail Knowing the Deadly Risk to Passengers and Crew
summary: Resume Subscription. Early in March, the world's cruise-ship operators had ample evidence to believe their fleet of luxury liners were incubators for the new coronavirus.

title: Mysteries: A Shattered Lens
summary: Sara Sligar's debut thriller is, by turns, a West Coast art-world satire, an erotic romance and a descent into madness.. Kate Aitken, the ex-journalist at the forefront of Sara Sligar's circuitous first novel, "Take Me Apart" (MCD, 358 pages, $27), seems, at age 30, a burnt-out case. Forced to leave her newspaper job in New York after filing a complaint about the sexual harassment she suffered from a colleague, she had a breakdown and then abandoned her Manhattan career for the West Coast: "She wanted to believe California could fix it all: tan her wan skin, shine her dull hair, and . . . reach down into the broken, taped-together mess inside her and repair that, too."

title: Fiction: Logbook of a Marriage
summary: A young, nautical New England couple tries to renew their vows during a yearlong voyage in the Caribbean.. 'Marriages have failure points, just like boats," says the matriarch of a "cruising family" in Amity Gaige's novel "Sea Wife" (Knopf, 267 pages, $26.95), explaining what happens to couples who choose to make their home at sea. "You sail a boat through rough weather and the failure points are revealed. . . . If you would rather not know the failure points," she advises, "do not go sailing."

title: Israel Mulls Coronavirus Points System After Lockdown
summary: Points would be assigned to individuals based on their health and age to help them decide if to stay at home after restrictions are lifted. TEL AVIV-As Israel begins to lift lockdowns aimed at containing the spread of the coronavirus, the government is considering a points-based system to help determine who should consider isolating even after measures are removed.

title: As Europe's Economy Founders, ECB Signals Readiness to Act
summary: Chief economist says ECB stands ready to counter rising borrowing costs among eurozone members. FRANKFURT-The European Central Bank intends to counter any surge in borrowing costs of eurozone governments, a senior bank official said, driving home the message that the ECB will support members such as Spain and Italy in responding to the worst economic downturn since World War II.

title: Open the Economy and Protect Those at Risk
summary: This is our opportunity to set the younger generations free and help prevent a prolonged and devastating social and economic calamity.. Avik Roy's "Reopening the U.S. Economy Even if the Pandemic Endures" (Review, April 25) gets it right. It is the responsibility of those of us who are the "at risk" populations-over 65 or documented co-morbidities-to minimize our own risk for exposure to SARS-CoV-2 through social distancing and personal protective measures. Local, state and federal support programs should be directed at this at-risk population to prevent social isolation and the associated anxiety, depression and related co-morbidities, financial support for those with inadequate resources, local home food delivery and designated senior shopping and dining restaurant hours.

title: Don't Be Prejudiced Against Homeschooling
summary: Avoiding "mainstream culture," a source of Ms. Bartholet's animus toward homeschooling, is possibly the best reason for its maintenance.. Samuel James is much too kind, and perhaps defensive, in opposing Elizabeth Bartholet's denunciation of homeschooling ("A Harvard Professor Shows Her Prejudice Against Homeschoolers," op-ed, April 25). Behind the outcries alleging the many horrors of learning at home, one must consider the progressive agenda, i.e., maintaining a close allegiance with public education, one of the foremost supporters of the left. Possibly, Ms. Bartholet realizes that many parents would fail to promote transgenderism, gender fluidity, white guilt, diversity, multiculturalism and anticapitalism, to name a few themes. There is also the matter of religion, which the left opposes, except for the worship of government.

title: Honoring a Humble, Brave, Yet Almost Unknown Hero
summary: Maurice Dotson wasn't a captain of industry, he didn't found a multimillion dollar company, and he didn't have wealth or stature.. I have long enjoyed reading the Saturday obituaries, and learning of the amazing life stories told there. You feature captains of industry, household names, corporate founders, CEOs and inventors, people of wealth, stature and success. I was surprised and very moved to read the obituary for Maurice Dotson, nursing assistant, who passed away from Covid-19 ("Nursing Assistant Kept Showing Up," Obituaries, April 25). Mr. Dotson wasn't a captain of industry, he didn't found a multimillion dollar company, and he didn't have wealth or stature. But to his family, and to the residents of the West Oaks Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, he was a hero. He stayed by their side, taking care of them, despite great personal risk.

title: The Down and Dirty Story of Scrubs Beyond Hospitals
summary: Hospitals, at least the one I worked for, didn't want to pay for washing scrubs.. In "Why Are Counterprotesters in Scrubs?" (op-ed, April 25), Dr. Michael Segal says, "in the 1980s, we were forbidden to leave the hospital in scrubs . . . to avoid bringing infections out on scrubs or bringing dirt in." He goes on to say: "At some time that changed." It changed because hospitals, at least the one I worked for, didn't want to pay for washing scrubs; they passed the cost onto the employee.

title: Thinly Staffed Nursing Homes Face Challenges in Pandemic
summary: For-profit companies had tighter staffing on average before coronavirus hit, analysis shows. Nursing homes around the U.S. are facing a staffing crisis, as the coronavirus sidelines members of a workforce that was already thinly stretched in many facilities before the pandemic.

title: Finding Your Balance in a Topsy-Turvy Market
summary: Taking calm, contrarian action in a crazy world is a great way to restore balance-not only to your portfolio, but to your frame of mind. The market wisdom that sounds the easiest can be the hardest to follow.

title: V-E Day Forged a World Still Worth Defending
summary: 75 years ago, the Allies brought the Nazi threat to an end with resolve, endurance, sacrifice and leaders who knew the importance of working together. Almost 75 years ago, on May 8, 1945, the pathogen of Nazism was finally eradicated with Germany's unconditional surrender to the Allies, after six years of war and tens of millions dead. The jubilation was tempered by exhaustion, sorrow and a stark awareness that World War II hadn't yet run its course in the Pacific, a bloody finale that would require another four months and two atomic bombs.

title: Exxon Posts First Loss in Decades as Oil Giants Signal Trouble Ahead
summary: Exxon and Chevron slashed spending and projected a difficult year ahead due to the coronavirus pandemic. Exxon Mobil Corp. posted its first quarterly loss in three decades as it and rival Chevron Corp. painted a dismal picture of the oil industry, signaling that the impact of the coronavirus pandemic may hang over their businesses for much of 2020.

title: Trump Makes Push for Seniors, as Coronavirus Crisis Erodes Support
summary: President trails Joe Biden in polls among older voters, who are paying close attention to his handling of the pandemic-and watching his press briefings. WASHINGTON-President Trump has opened a new charm offensive aimed at appealing to America's older voters, who polls show are souring on his re-election amid the coronavirus crisis.

title: PG&E Outlines Board Shake-Up as It Posts Quarterly Profit
summary: The California utility, facing billions in fire-related costs, had planned to overhaul its board to secure Gavin Newsom's support for its plan to exit bankruptcy. PG&E Corp. on Friday detailed a planned shake-up of its board of directors as it reported a rise in quarterly earnings.

title: Local, Practical, Apolitical: Inside Germany's Successful Coronavirus Strategy
summary: Nation's 16 states are unsung heroes of the battle; keeping factories open, health-care system prepared. BERLIN-Germany's success in battling the coronavirus pandemic has drawn international attention. The main lessons: Fight the virus locally, and keep politics out of it.

title: Dave Barry: The American Way Is To Muddle Through
summary: Your forebears also had to navigate paths of adversity. Though at least we didn't have your toilet-paper shortage.. I won't sugar-coat this: You're graduating in a depressing and scary time. So I will begin with some words from Abraham Lincoln, who in 1861, during another dark time in our history-a time when people desperately needed a reason to hope-said, quote: "Well, THIS sucks."

title: Terry Lenzner Cultivated Fearsome Reputation as Sleuth for Hire
summary: Watergate investigator offered his skills to corporate clients; his agents sifted Microsoft's trash. After graduating from Harvard Law School in 1964, Terry Lenzner was determined not to have a conventional legal career. He succeeded spectacularly.

title: Iran Satellite Launch Reveals Gains in Missile Program
summary: U.S. officials, experts see military milestone fueling development of intercontinental ballistic missiles. When Iran launched its first military satellite into orbit last week, commanders in the control center erupted in cheers, some of them wearing surgical masks to protect against the new coronavirus, others kissing the bare cheeks of their comrades.

title: AI Funds Decline-Then Recover-During Market Turmoil
summary: Traders that use machine learning have had to adjust strategies and rely less on historical data to train models. Hedge funds that use artificial intelligence models to suggest trades and stock picks declined when stock markets unraveled in late February, but now have largely recovered, according to benchmarks tracking these strategies.

title: Asia Keeps Up Oil Imports, and the Savings Add Up
summary: Demand for crude remains strong in China, but lower prices go only so far in easing coronavirus damage. Low oil prices are likely to help Asia's largest economies restart as they begin to emerge from the worst of the coronavirus pandemic, although the lower cost isn't a panacea.

title: New Measures of Social Distancing Could Be This Generation's GDP
summary: Companies and governments look to give public a single number or letter grade to show progress in preventing coronavirus spread. The Great Depression of the 1930s catalyzed the creation of modern economic indicators such as gross domestic product and the unemployment rate, so governments could better judge the success of their policies.

title: The 2011 NFL Lockout Holds Lessons for the Coronavirus Season
summary: Almost a decade ago, teams were unable to meet or practice in the off-season due to a labor dispute. There's now a similar situation amid the pandemic.. It's impossible to understand the NFL in 2020 without the players drafted nine years ago. The first two picks were future MVP Cam Newton and Super Bowl MVP Von Miller. J.J. Watt, the 11th pick, is still the most disruptive defensive lineman in the league and fifth-rounder Richard Sherman remains one of the best cornerbacks. There were star receivers like Julio Jones and A.J. Green, plus a star quarterback named Colin Kaepernick who slipped to the second round.

title: Honeywell Posts Lower Sales Amid Covid-19 Supply-Chain Disruptions
summary: Company reports higher profit as expenses fell, withdraws 2020 guidance. Honeywell International Inc. said its profit rose for the first quarter, though sales fell and the company withdrew its financial guidance for the year as the coronavirus pandemic has disrupted supply chains.

title: A Smartphone App Tries to Guide the Way Out of Coronavirus Lockdowns
summary: Researchers seek to identify Covid-19 hot spots and suggest some early symptoms have been missed. Its organizers call it the "biggest citizen science project in health that we have ever seen anywhere in the world."

title: Editor Kristina O'Neill on Remote-Editing the May Issue
summary: Our editor in chief on the May 2020 issue of 'WSJ. Magazine,' our first-ever finished entirely remotely. Magazine making is a team effort. Producing this issue-our first-ever finished entirely remotely-took that truism to the next level. Sequestered at home offices and kitchen tables, often with young children underfoot, our nimble staff of editors, designers, production people, copy editors and fact checkers developed a new, all-digital workflow, proving that even in quarantine, it takes a village. I'd like to thank my entire team for navigating these challenging times with such calm professionalism.

title: Contributors to the May 2020 Issue
summary: The writers and photographers who helped make the issue come to life. Photographer Robbie Lawrence and writer Madeleine Speed traveled to South Africa's Stellenbosch region to meet with pioneering winemakers, all women of color, who are transforming the industry. "The entrepreneurs and winemakers we met were smart, resilient and great businesswomen. But crucially-a lot of fun," Speed says of the women, whose jobs turned out to involve as much grit as grapes. "I was intrigued by the physical nature of winemaking-there is little glamour to the process," says Lawrence, noting that he focused on the hands-on element in his photos. Speed remembers feeling relaxed on the wine farms while coming to terms with their murky past. "Stellenbosch is an old-school paradise," she says. "But the region has a dark side." The most difficult part of writing the story was, she says, "finding ways to reconcile the wealth and beauty of the region with the legacy of apartheid buried just beneath the surface."

title: Warm-Weather Wardrobes, for Him and for Her
summary: As the days get longer and temperatures rise, streamlined summery styles with crisp whites and light knits are a breath of fresh air. SEA CHANGE Nautical touches and a subtle palette offer a light touch. On him: Hermès sweater, $1,750, Hermès stores nationwide, Ann Demeulemeester pants, $806, anndemeulemeester.com, Tiffany & Co. bracelet (worn throughout), $6,800, tiffany.com and vintage Vans sneakers. On her: Alexander McQueen dress, price upon request, Alexander McQueen Madison Avenue, New York, Verdura earrings, $7,950, verdura.com, Tiffany & Co. rings (worn throughout), $1,500 and $5,000, tiffany.com, Prada sandals, price upon request, prada.com

title: The Six Best-Designed Items of May
summary: From watches and rugs to the world's most stunningly artistic globe, see what's caught the eye of WSJ. Magazine editors this month. During the 1930s, Louis Cartier combined diamonds and slices of carved rock crystal in a striking set of geometric cuffs that was purchased by the actress Gloria Swanson. "Cartier used crystal for the sake of volume," explains Pierre Rainero, the house's image, style and heritage director, who returned to the talismanic minerals for Cartier's Magnitude High Jewelry collection. The necklace and earrings shown here fuse diamonds and rutilated quartz crystal, with its threads of gold-colored inclusions, imparting an organic sensibility to the precious jewels in a way that plays with scale, texture and light. -Jill Newman

title: Amazon's Battle for the Air Just Got Easier
summary: Airlines are dumping old planes, giving the e-commerce giant the perfect opportunity to expand its cargo fleet at a time of constrained supply. Dominating the skies has been the key to winning many wars. The time is right for Amazon to build up its air force.

title: Coal Producers Struggle After Years of Investor Payouts
summary: Big miners spent heavily on dividends and buybacks during good times, leaving them struggling as sales tumble. In the coal industry's long decline, the years 2017 and 2018 were pretty good ones. But instead of stashing away cash for tough times, coal producers spent billions of dollars in dividends and stock buybacks to benefit their investors.

title: Rent Is Due Today, but Many Tenants Can't-or Won't-Pay
summary: Landlords brace for collecting less than in April as unemployment soars amid the coronavirus pandemic. May is shaping up as a clash between renters and landlords, as soaring unemployment could leave millions of tenants unable to pay, and some organizers of rent strikes urge even those with means to hold back.

title: Your Spit Could Be the Best Coronavirus Test
summary: As states look for ways to increase their testing capacity, new research suggests that saliva is as effective detecting the virus as swabs. Swabs or spit?

title: Scandal-Struck Luckin Coffee Loses Its Technology Chief
summary: He Gang resigns for personal reasons after just seven months on the job. Luckin Coffee Inc.'s chief technology officer has resigned, people familiar with the matter said, another blow to a chain embroiled in a major faked-revenue scandal.

title: These Magic Tricks Let Kids Wow Grandparents on Zoom
summary: Ideal for quarantine, these video tutorials-plus a willing parental assistant-help children master confounding illusions. FOR KIDS, MAGIC tricks can trigger both wonder and frustration. Learning to persuasively perform even the simplest illusion takes discipline, concentration and time-an abundance of which we're struggling to fill now. theory11, a New York company that supplies tricks to novices and pros, offers easy-to-follow video tutorials demonstrating the mechanics of tricks they sell, plus tips for performance and patter that an aspiring Houdini needs to engage an audience of bored, skeptical siblings. The first two tricks here are free after you register at the theory11 site and all three work just as well over Zoom as in person.

title: European Soccer Has Started Giving Up
summary: France became the first of Europe's top five leagues to abandon its season on Thursday. And delays are piling up for the rest.. PARIS-Somewhere on a video conference Thursday, 61 days since its most recent league game, Paris Saint-Germain was crowned France's soccer champion. There was no trophy ceremony and there will be no parade.

title: Betting on Health Care May Be Hazardous To Your Wealth
summary: Seeking shelter in the health-care sector during a medical crisis seems like a no-brainer, but much of the industry is vulnerable to fallout from the coronavirus crisis.. Health care has been a reliable place for investors to shelter during recessions. It would seem even safer in a recession caused by a health crisis, but things aren't so simple.

title: Investors Bet Oil Crash Will Weaken Middle East Currency Pegs
summary: Drop in oil revenue is putting pressure on governments to borrow more to cushion the economy from the coronavirus. Managed foreign-exchange rates in the Persian Gulf have survived financial crises, oil-price crashes and military conflicts. But crude's recent drop to historic lows is tempting investors to bet against currency pegs once again.

title: Coronavirus Slows but Won't Halt Shipping's Focus on Global Trade
summary: Ocean carriers say big ships and globalization will remain key to supply chains, many linked to China. The coronavirus pandemic has exposed the fragile nature of businesses and economies built on the flow of goods around the world, with supply chains rattled by factory shutdowns, expensive ships sitting idle and cargo terminals closed for the lack of trade.

title: Stocks Return to Their Winning Ways in Week of Extremes
summary: Here is a look at the week's winners and losers. This was a week of extremes. The economic data continue to be awful. Gross domestic product in the first quarter fell at its worst rate since the last recession. Consumer spending in March dropped to its lowest rate since 1959. Second-quarter data will be worse, and hope for a recovery is still just that: hope.

title: Parties Plan for Regulatory Rollback Role Reversal
summary: Liberal groups prepare lists of new regulations Congress could cancel if Joe Biden beats President Trump; aid for fisheries surfaces in stimulus talks. PARTIES PREPARE FOR POSSIBLE REGULATORY ROLLBACK if former Vice President Joe Biden wins the presidency and Democrats control Congress. While Congress is currently occupied by the coronavirus pandemic, liberal organizations are preparing lists of regulations that Congress could cancel by simple majority votes in the early months of a Biden administration, and conservatives are urging agencies to hurry up and finish pending rules.

title: As Tele-Counseling Booms, a Therapist Seeks Respite
summary: Amy Cirbus balances a surge in demand for teletherapy sessions during the pandemic with being 'present' for her kids. Dr. Amy Cirbus is finding it hard to get away from her job as a therapist and director of clinical content at a company called Talkspace. Simple things-like taking a peaceful walk or tucking her children in-take serious planning during a pandemic.

title: These Businesses Won't Bounce Back From Coronavirus
summary: The pattern of a previous crisis suggests that investors should avoid industries already suffering from underlying health conditions. How different could the post-coronavirus world look? Predictions of radical change abound, such as working from home becoming the norm. But a more certain outcome of the pandemic is the accelerated demise of industries that were already in decline.

title: 3.8 Million More Sought Jobless Benefits as Surge Tests States' Systems
summary: Archaic technology hamstrings systems for processing benefits; 'not really acceptable now'. Nearly four million people filed for unemployment benefits last week, bringing total claims to more than 30 million as states struggle to process an unprecedented wave triggered by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Deaths From Coronavirus Top 63,000 as Crisis Slams Economies
summary: More than 3.8 million Americans file for jobless benefits; eurozone economy suffers sharpest contraction on record. Stay-at-home orders in parts of America were set to expire Thursday, as the coronavirus pandemic's deadliest month so far drew to a close and confirmed U.S. fatalities exceeded 63,000.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Greek Yogurt Pancake Recipe: What to Cook in Quarantine
summary: The yogurt in this recipe keeps the pancakes moist and fluffy, and also gives them a pleasant tang. It's comforting just looking at a stack of pancakes, griddled until evenly golden, a pat of butter melting into a pool on top.

title: IRS Denies Tax Deductions Tied to Small-Business Loans
summary: If loans get forgiven, employers can't take deductions related to tax-exempt income, agency says. WASHINGTON-Small businesses that get their loans forgiven can't take tax deductions for associated wages and other expenses, the IRS said in a ruling that shrinks the potential value of the popular Paycheck Protection Program.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond Names New CFO as Part of Ongoing Management Refocus
summary: Gustavo Arnal joins the struggling home-goods retailer from Avon. Bed Bath & Beyond Inc. named a new finance chief as part of a wider management refocus that the struggling home-goods retailer embarked on before the downturn from the coronavirus lockdowns began.

title: Boeing Launches $25 Billion Bond Sale
summary: Aerospace giant may avoid immediate need for federal funding after huge investor demand creates biggest non-M&A deal. Boeing Co. launched Thursday a $25 billion bond offering that it said met near-term financial requirements and for now avoided any federal funding to ride out the coronavirus crisis that has engulfed the global airline industry.

title: McConnell Defends Decision for Senate to Convene Amid Virus
summary: Democrats say move will place lawmakers and staff at risk as Washington maintains stay-at-home order. WASHINGTON-Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stood by his decision to convene the Senate next week, saying it was elected officials' duty to return to work amid the coronavirus outbreak, despite criticism from Democrats that it will put lawmakers and staff at risk.

title: University of Notre Dame to Reject Federal Stimulus Money
summary: Tensions over private Indiana school's funding is part of broader political debate. The University of Notre Dame joined the growing list of top rated schools turning back public funds in the wake of political pressure from Republican elected officials.
